title: Level horizon from QGC doesn't survive reboot
Pixracer: MANUAL CONTROL LOST on param save
body:
When landing, the flight duration param is set, leading to a param save. On pixracer, this causes a manual control loss and failsafe mode switch. The following shows the order of events (timestamps in ms), on #6901 branch:
```
nsh> WARN  [land_detector] param land set 24929
WARN  [land_detector] param land set 24929 done
INFO  [commander] Landing detected
WARN  [modules__systemlib] entering param_save_default 25229 
WARN  [commander] MANUAL CONTROL LOST (at t=25739ms)
INFO  [commander_tests] no RC
WARN  [commander] failsafe mode on
INFO  [commander] Takeoff detected
WARN  [modules__systemlib] param_save_default done 26424
WARN  [commander] failsafe mode off
```

And this shows the sampling is thrown off during param save (timestamps do not match the above output):
![manual_control_loss_pixracer_sampling](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/281593/24350573/f94da35a-12e2-11e7-967d-cc24eaa3d383.png)

Happens both on master (8810f70fdcf036b with nuttx semaphore patch) and with https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/6901

This is not a prio inversion/inheritance problem, all task priorities stay the same. The problem is that we disable interrupts during save, apparently for too long, throwing off RC and sensor sampling, done here: https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/systemlib/param/param.c#L922. If I comment out this lock, the problem disappears.

@davids5 can you look into that?

title: Takeoff overshoot in real world but not in the simulator
body:
When I ask the drone to take off to 5 meters it shoots aggressively up to 10 meters then comes back down:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18707114/24180121/4e9fbc48-0e70-11e7-8c1c-51aff459651c.png)

[14-25-29-input.zip](https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/files/860207/14-25-29-input.zip)

Looking at the code in mc_pos_control, around line 1561 under the comment "special thrust setpoint generation for takeoff from ground" I see that it ramps up throttle all the way to MPC_THR_MAX if necessary in order to get the drone off the ground, and when it detects drone has reached MPC_TKO_SPEED speed then it switches to normal setpoint altitude hold.  The problem I see with this is that the GPS sensor is very slow, so it always cranks to MPC_THR_MAX for very agressive takeoff.  

I want to fix this, but I could use some pointers.  I don't want any new parameters, we already have too many, instead I would love the code to be self tuning, for example, if I strap something heavy on my drone, it should "just work".  I assume that the current behavior came about because you also do not want the drone to "hop" during takeoff because then it thinks it has landed again and disarms.  

But clearly from the picture above, PWM shot all the way to up max throttle (90% of 1950 is 1755) before it even detected drone leaving the ground, then because the acceleration was so great, even with PWM falling quickly to 1283, the drone was essentially flung up to 10 meters.    What is very interesting is the red line I drew on the PWM signal.  Drone is still ascending quickly, and PWM is going up??? from 1283 to 1443.  I realize you don't want the drone to freefall, but there must be something wrong there.

So I propose to add a takeoff that is more gentle, like landing.  Where it slowly spins up the props just to get some idea of what it takes to get any vertical acceleration.  For example, when I look at the charts, z-mag responded 1 full second before GPS noticed any change.  In fact, z-mag was seeing something when PWM was way down at 1100.  This slow ramp up ensures safety, if anyone is near they will back off before it shoots up into the air.  So from there it should ramp up quickly to HOVER_THROTTLE + some delta, where that delta is self tuning.  This sudden ramp will cause a hop, but to keep it in the air we need more than hover throttle, so it can start more aggressively to ensure no hops, but then it will write a private setting to calibrate this value so that the next take off will be smoother and smoother each time you try it.  This is a little bit like auto-tuning a PID algorithm I suppose.

Any objections or better ideas ?

title: Offboard attitude control completely broken/unuseable
body:
I posted a similar issue in #6830 but got no response. I have now confirmed that it is not just in simulation, but also when the firmware is run on actual hardware.

There are large delays between when an attitude setpoint is set and when the px4 begins tracking the setpoint. See the images below. Note that I am comparing the setpoints the px4 itself is sending back over mavlink (via the setpoint loopback topic in mavros) to the actual attitude via a mocap system. This rules out any issue in ROS/mavros/mavlink/telemetry communication between companion computer and px4. Also, the mocap has a low latency connection to the plot computer, whereas mavros is over wireless, so the actual delay is even larger than what it noted below.

![lag1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3847301/24171850/aa2a9a30-0e4b-11e7-86ee-d43ff57b0e03.png)
Observe the time period 1283-1285 seconds, where the x coordinate of the orientation (gold) steadily decreases, but the actual copter (blue) does not respond for 2 seconds! And throughout the time period pictured, there is a 0.25-0.5 second delay between commands and response.

![lag2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3847301/24172071/813610e0-0e4c-11e7-8e25-ac89cfe2cb7c.png)
Again notice the ~0.3 second delay in tracking. Also notice the weirdness at 1314-1315 seconds. The copter begins tracking, then pauses for 0.5 s, and then jumps to tracking again!?! Same thing at 1318-1320s.

Please help!

title: LPE Alt.amsl and Alt.relative not initialized properly with Px4Flow estimation only
body: With latest master, LPE using LIDAR and PX4Flow only does not initialize Alt.amsl at start-up (landed state). As Alt.amsl seems to be required for Alt.terrain, no relative altitude (Alt.agl) is determined. As a consequence, PX4Flow is not scaled properly due to missing Alt.agl figures. If position information e.g. vision is fused on ground, this problem does not occur. Additionally, global position is not initialized as well (even with LPE_FAKE_ORIGIN=1).

title: attitude tracking
body:
Tested in SITL:
it seems that the transformation from quaternion to roll,pitch and yaw are not done correctly and do not represent what actually happens. giving roll command, the tracking of the roll setpoint seems to be correct at the beginning, but over time the logged roll setpoint is opposite the estimated roll. title: LandDetector Bug

milestone.title: Release v1.6.0
milestone.description: The main novelty of this release is a massive NuttX update adding support for STM32F7 and fault logging.

body:
Can't take off after the first flight in Altitude mode.
Because of this line:
https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/land_detector/LandDetector.cpp#L206
This line will never works until we leave landed state:
https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/land_detector/MulticopterLandDetector.cpp#L214
So,if we arm in altitude mode ,this line will be the only chance to takeoff:
https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/land_detector/MulticopterLandDetector.cpp#L239
It's looks good for the first time to takeoff.
But,when we landed and disarmed after the first flight.
_min_trust_start !=0 after we landed,because we returned from https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/land_detector/MulticopterLandDetector.cpp#L204  ,and we did not reset "_min_trust_start"  to zero.
In this case ,we can't takeoff after the first flight if we are in altitude mode with no position lock.

Maybe we could never takeoff if we are in altitude mode and have position locked?

title: Preflight EKF error checking is linked to GPS
body:
If bad IMU data causes the EKF error checks here to fail here: 

https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/commander/PreflightCheck.cpp#L690-L698 ,

then the failure to arm could be interpreted by the user as a GPS error. If the user then decides to fly without GPS, they will set COM_ARM_WO_GPS =1 to bypass the check and be unaware that there is a problem with the IMU. This can lead to a loss of height, position and possibly attitude control.

**Work Required**

1) Check error reporting messages for the EKF checks and rectify if misleading.
2) Add a unique circuit breaker for the EKF checks
3) Update documentation to reflect the changes

title: Crash in certain modes when using vmount
body:
See http://discuss.px4.io/t/pixracer-1-5-5-fly-away/2507/7 for full discussion regarding this issue.

When using the vmount driver and switching to any of the non-manual modes (Auto Hold, Offboard, Follow me) the system stops responding to any RC input, QGC looses the connection, logging stops, and all fail-safes are ignored.
Notable is that during the initial fly-away the stabilisation was working and the drone kept its position (not the altitude though) until the battery ran out.

Steps to reproduce:
Equipment:
* PixRacer, no props, tested indoors
* PX4 1.5.5 stable via Qgroundcontrol
* extras.txt with:
```
#start mount driver
vmount start
set MNT_MODE_IN 2
set MNT_MODE_OUT 0
set MNT_MAN_CONTROL 1
set MNT_MAN_PITCH 2
```
* Telemetry link to Linux machine with Uart example code (https://github.com/mavlink/c_uart_interface_example)

After Take-off in manual mode launch uart example program. As soon as the program switches the flight mode to OFFBOARD the system stops responding.

It was reported by another user that this behaviour also happens on a Pixhawk 2.4.5 using the PX4 current master.

title: S.BUS scanner: Do only execute if HW inverter is present

title: Auto Pause: Total disaster.
body:
Today I had a total crash with a novice while I was teaching him how to fly the PX4!

Why?? Just because he could not understand nor he could learn that in order to PAUSE his flight he has to 

FIRST: switch to MISSION
and then
SECOND: to switch Auto Pause

it is just overwhelming for the pilot to think of this combination, especially in dare situation when you most likely need Auto Pause. It is against all the rules in a real airplane cockpit as well.

It is crazzzzyyyy!

It is like having your phone ringing in a meeting and then in order to MUTE it you have to first hit home button and then hold volume down for 2 seconds.

Or it is like if you are in the car listening to music CD and have your phone ringing first hit on the Radio Button and then hit CD pause in order to Pause your CD.

Now I have to make an input mixer setting in the Horus in order to do it with just one button, given all the processing power I have in the Pixhawk. Is it hard to make it function like RTL?

This becomes the N1 reason for crashes of novice for the last 6 months I experience. Nobody wants to fly PX4 at the club already. And it is hard for me to persuade them to start using it again with such public crashes and disaster in front of all people and humiliation for me!

It is non sense, period.

Or maybe I'm stupid and I'm missing some hidden parameter that should allow this. If this is the case excuse me for the rant.

title: Horizontal velocity control input delay
body: If you have the cruise velocity high, the maximum tilt angle pretty low and the slew rate (maximal horizontal acceleration) on a reasonably low value you experience a pretty noticable delay between command and vehicle reaction. This problem was also reported in atomatic flight modes. Digging into it @Stifael and I found out that the velocity controller looses close tracking because of the tilt angle limitation while the setpoint goes to your high valued cruise velocity. Now if you want to stop or fly the oposite direction again, the slew rate prevents the fast setpoint change and the vehicle shows no reaction at all at least for the time the velocity setpoint is still higher than the actual velocity. Here is a plot showing this effect with high cruise velocity of > 10m/s, a very small maximum tilt angle of 10 degree to clearly show the problem, and a reasonable maximum acceleration of the same value as the crusie velocity > 10 m/s^2. turquoise stick input, yellow velocity setpoint, red attitude setpoint It looks to me that this problem is closely related to https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/6681

title: RTL mode state is not being reset to NONE
body:
When RTL mode is being deactivated, and then re-activate, the RTL mode is not always goes to RTL_STATE_NONE.
On some case it is, if for example a mission is being triggered on between.
It can be easily reproduced on the simulator (iris, ekf2)
1) takeoff
2) fly to another location (you must fly, another bug is that RTL is not started if triggered just after takeoff)
3) start RTL 
4) the drone will climb (RTL_STATE_CLIMB)
5) the drone will return home (RTL_STATE_RETURN)
6) the drone will start descending (RTL_STATE_DESCEND)
7) pause the drone
8) fly to another location
9) start RTL again
10) (BUG here) instead of starting the RTL from beginning (step 4) it will continue from it last state (in this case descending)

its much more critical if during RTL mode its goes as far to RTL_STATE_LAND mode. 
its seems that a call to set_can_loiter_at_sp(true) should be done on some places on the code (which I am not sure where)

title: Param not saved - (storage is FRAM)
body:
We crashed one of our prototypes today due to a parameter that didnt store.
The param is question was PWM_AUX2_REV, the following happened;

A new FC as mounted and a bench test was done.
Elevons needed reversing so they were set through QGC.
After setting a bench test was done on the elevons and they performed as required.
Then we went to the field and started a transition, the plane crashed right after transition.
Post-mortem analysis indicated PWM_AUX1_REV was set to 1 but PWM_AUX2_REV was at 0
We managed to test the params on the original wings and indeed the response was incorrect.

The deduced bug is that the param was loaded in memory but it failed to write to flash. QGC showed no warning upon storing the param.

![dq5 crash](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14801663/23313426/f00ca6ac-fabd-11e6-86f7-601e444cee40.jpeg)

title: Takeoff not detected after 2nd time in altitude mode
body:
Hello
With release v1.6.0rc1 or the current master the takeoff seems not to be detected after the second time arming in altitude mode:
http://review.px4.io/plot_app?log=b29f4633-e7c9-49a9-ab92-18106d9f01f9

```
2017_02_23_09_31_15: [logger] file: /fs/microsd/log/2017-02-23/09_31_1
2017_02_23_09_34_09: ARMED by RC
2017_02_23_09_34_11: Takeoff detected
2017_02_23_09_34_29: Landing detected
2017_02_23_09_34_31: DISARMED by auto disarm on land
2017_02_23_09_34_36: ARMED by RC
2017_02_23_09_34_46: DISARMED by auto disarm on land
```
The first time arming in altitude, the takeoff and landing is detected fine.
After the 2nd time arming, the motors are only spinning with idle thrust for some seconds and the attitude/position controller is not responding to any rc commands or nick/roll movement.
In case I switch to e.g. stabilized mode and then back to altitude mode again (when the motors are spinning with idle thrust) the takeoff is detected, the motors are spinning up and the attitude/position controller seems to be working again.

title: Mavlink stream rate & connection with QGC
body:
Hello all.
 
I recently bought Pixhawk Mini. Currently, I am setting the hardware to establish ROS-Pixhawk-GCS system.

In the previous Pixhawk it provided TELEM2 port which can be connected to the ROS-computer directly. However, Mini provides only one TELEM1 port which is assigned for Wifi-module now. The last port I can use is the port with 'Android'? cable used when bootloading. I successfully increased the stream rate of that port by adding a file to the SD card in /etc/extras.txt.

The content is as follows :
mavlink stream -d /dev/ttyACM0 -s HIGHRES_IMU -r 200
mavlink stream -d /dev/ttyACM0 -s LOCAL_POSITION_NED -r 200
mavlink stream -d /dev/ttyACM0 -s ATTITUDE_QUATERNION -r 200

With that file, Mini now provides high frequency data about 170hz with the 'Android' port.

However, when I try to connect Mini from QGC, it shows no response at all although I connect my wifi well with low ping.

When I remove the extras.txt file again, QGC can communicate with Mini very well.

1. Any idea how I can change the stream rate without affecting the Wifi module(TELEM1)?
2. As I know, The 'Android' port is assigned with ttyS0 and the TELEM1 port is ttyS1. But all people I saw use ttyACM0. When I tried to use ttyS0 instead of ACM0 in extras.txt file, it failed.

Thank you for time.

title: Landing initialization
body:
1.) Currently ground contact and landing are set to 0 at initialization, which is wrong since at start, when not armed, they both should be 1. 
![landing_initalization](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/13449161/23129627/ae0d697c-f783-11e6-9028-5bb48316ba96.png)

2.) Currently only landed or groundcontact can occur simultaneously. This is confusing since the state-name "landed" implies that it also has "groundcontact". One solution is to change the name "groundcontact" to "maybe_landed" or we change the logic such that both states can be true.

title: Fix dataman and allow more waypoints
body:
The dataman started overwriting contents after 256 items because the
item index were only uint8_t. This fix allows for more than 256
waypoints.

Since using more than 256 mission items has been tested and fixed, the
limit can now be raised to more than 256 (but smaller than UINT16_MAX).

Since the whole file is allocated in advance on NuttX, the limit there
is (arbitrarily) set to 2000. For POSIX archs such as SITL, we don't
really need to constrain ourselves any longer.

Found together with @bkueng.
You might be interested to review @AndreasAntener, I think, you asked in the past what the state was.

Tested with up to 65000 mission items using SITL and 400 on a Pixracer.

@LorenzMeier am I missing any architecture setup to test?

title: Battery failsafe action can be interrupted unintentionally
body:
Currently if a critical battery failsafe action is being performed, it's pretty easy to unintentionally kick it out of a battery failsafe without realizing it.
It's related to what's happening here: https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blob/master/src/modules/commander/commander.cpp#L2481
Meant to deal with geofence violations it seems but also triggers on battery failsafe.

RTL kicked in (set to 50 meter radius), and it brought the drone home and during landing user wanted to nudge the x-y position a bit, but as soon as they touched the sticks the drone immediately switched to stabilize mode, and drone started to plummet until user realized and ramped up throttle to catch the free fall.  I love the idea of being able to nudge the drone while landing (like Solo) but it would be nice if this didn't turn off auto-landing.  This was using latest PX4 master bits from 1/25/2017 with ekf2.

See [log description ](http://www.lovettsoftware.com/Downloads/Bugs/RTLIssue.png)and [actual PX4 log](http://logs.uaventure.com/view/6MLvpYmTqh7N5YerRHjRug).

title: cmake nuttx binary naming fix
body:
@LorenzMeier - With this PR the nuttx binaries (.px4) are now named in the same form QGC expects for S3. For example px4fmu-v2_default is now named `px4fmu-v2_default.px4` instead of `nuttx-px4fmu-v2-default.px4` which was then erroneously renamed to `px4fmu-v2-default.px4`.

The naming of the binaries uploaded to S3 for QGC has been wrong for about 2 weeks now. Dashes instead of underscores.

title: Fixed twitch/spike during mode switch
body:
The special calculation for switching from a non-velocity controlled mode into a velocity controlled mode is not needed anymore with the recently introduced feed forward thrust (see https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/blame/0d99ab91aad5a159de9c287383419245b1c6bcb8/src/modules/mc_pos_control/mc_pos_control_main.cpp#L1738).

It even produced unwanted aggressive twitches when still used.

I verified the change in SITL and also tested on a real model.
I got smooth breakdowns when switching from maual to position mode.

title: pixracer stops responding after mission upload
body:
Pixracer running current PX4 stable FW with EKF2 stops responding when syncing a mission. 

    It is very easy to repeat, I can be in any mode and all that I have to do is reupload a
    mission that either has too steep of a glideslope or one where the land waypoint is
    higher than the previous waypoint. It is fairly random when it occurs, sometimes it 
    happens on the second upload sometimes on the sixth or seventh but it is repeatable.

Occurs on multiple pixracers.


original post - http://discuss.px4.io/t/pixracer-board-lockup-in-flight/2232/19

title: Fix bug causing constant publishing of sensor corrections
body:
The exisiting logic used to determine if new sensor corrections should be published used a one degree change in sensor temperature as the trigger. When multiple sensor instances were present, the differences in reported temperature for each instance could cause continuous publishing.

This PR enables the publishing logic to monitor the change in temperature for each instance individually.

title: EKF2 performance poor in gazebo SITL with GPS
body:
Here is a 3-way comparison on master of EKF2, IEKF, and LPE for a SITL box mission with varying altitude. EKF2 fails on the first turn even before the climb. I think we might want to add an EKF2 multirotor test mission. I know the original thinking was that it was some server cpu limitation, but I can't get it to work locally either.

Maybe EKF2 could benefit from some noise tuning for SITL. For IEKF, I used [Allan variance plots](https://github.com/jgoppert/iekf_analysis/blob/master/SITL%20Noise%20Identification.ipynb)  for SITL and a [pixhawk](https://github.com/jgoppert/iekf_analysis/blob/master/Pixhawk%20Noise%20Identification.ipynb) for real life and really got great results. LPE is just using the same gains found manually from  flight testing.

title: Airspeed: Terrible problems again.
body:
Hello,

We've had a peaceful times without airspeed problems but the dreadful problems arose upon us again. :)

1. Five month ago we reported that we cannot arm the PX4 (the command arming) if the airspeed is flat 0 m/s. We had to blow in the pitot while arming in order to work. This is happening with EagleTree sensor which is much calmer than the original sensor and when on the ground it just stays at 0 m/s. In version 1.5.0 it is the same story. In order to arm we have to blow in the pitot...

2. In version 1.5.2 and 1.5.3 we could not perform a single successful airspeed calibration. Both versions are tested on two setups - AUAV + Original Sensor and Pixhawk + EagleTree sensor. In two different configs - VTOL and Airplane.

title: Incorrect units of variance in GPS topic
body:
Couple of issues and concerns which I had while upstreaming the GPS-VIO interface which will also allow an offboard estimator to use the GPS accuracy information: 

1 . This is from the `vehicle_gps_position` topic : 

```
float32 s_variance_m_s # GPS speed accuracy estimate, (metres/sec)
float32 c_variance_rad # GPS course accuracy estimate, (radians)
```

For velocity, variance should be in (m/s)^2 and for course, in rad^2. The comment and field name are both incorrect, and it is not understandable whether we want variance or standard deviation here.

1. From the mavlink message `GPS_INPUT` : 

```
speed_accuracy float GPS speed accuracy in m/s
horiz_accuracy float GPS horizontal accuracy in m
vert_accuracy float GPS vertical accuracy in m
```

The units suggest that these are standard deviations, however field spec is not clear from the word "accuracy". Judging from other messages with better docs e.g `WIND_COV` (horiz_accuracy float Horizontal speed 1-STD accuracy), it means sqrt variance.

1. Is there an objection to switching the `vehicle_gps_position` topic to covariances only (`pos_cov` and `vel_cov`), and derive the other uncertainty fields where needed? Seems kinda unnecessary to transport `hdop`, `vdop`, `epv`, `eph`, `s_variance_m_s`, `c_variance_rad`, etc. Also, modern estimators and any cascaded setup will benefit from the covariance availability. @LorenzMeier

I will send in a PR with the fixes and the new interface when as my concerns are confirmed by another pair of eyes.

title: Snapdragon muorb parameter update
body:
When doing a parameter update from QGC, the parameter is correctly updated on the krait side, but not on the dsp side. In fact, after a parameter update the value shown on the dsp is equal to the previous value from krait.
In order to reproduce this error: 
1.) choose a parameter such as MC_PITCHRATE_P
2.) open mc_att_control.cpp and do 	PX4_INFO("pitch rate: %.5f",(double)_params.rate_p(1)) somewhere in the code
3.) start px4 and open mini-dm
4.) open QGC
5.) change the parameter MC_PITCHRATE_P to a new value
-> observe the value that is printed in the mini-dm: it will show the previous value
6.) on krait side type: param show MC_PITCHRATE_P
-> it will show correctly the new updated value

title: MavLink and Logs missing Data
body:
Since 1.5.3 I have observed some hickups in the Logs (check: http://discuss.px4.io/t/various-issues-with-1-5-2-stable/2039/7) as well as a meesage from the OSD indicating that the Mavlink Stream has not send data for some time (Message : "Stream Frozen") for OSD with Firmware : https://github.com/night-ghost/minimosd-extra running on 57'600 Baud default Settings for FMUv2 on same Serial as Telemetry. This has been working prior to 1.5.2. 

Stream Frozen would occure in the actual OSD FW when there is no GPS Data in the MavLink Stream for more than 10 Cycles. In earlier Versions the Threshold was even as low as 5 Cycles and I have never seen this meesage. 

I suspect a common Problem for the low Log Rate and the Frozen MAVLINK Stream.

title: Mavlink rate control is still wonky
body:
So I'm trying to validate the 250 Hz data transfer result from https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/pull/6169, but something still isn't right.

I'm using the USB CDC interface on a Pixhawk, starting only a few streams in mavlink custom mode : 

Here's how I'm starting mavlink : 

```
# Mavlink
mavlink start -r 800000 -d /dev/ttyACM0 -m custom -x

# VIO Specific Streams
mavlink stream -d /dev/ttyACM0 -s HIGHRES_IMU 			-r 200
mavlink stream -d /dev/ttyACM0 -s GPS_RAW_INT 			-r 5
mavlink stream -d /dev/ttyACM0 -s ATTITUDE_QUATERNION 		-r 30
mavlink stream -d /dev/ttyACM0 -s CAMERA_TRIGGER 		-r 1000
mavlink stream -d /dev/ttyACM0 -s TIMESYNC 			-r 30
mavlink stream -d /dev/ttyACM0 -s SYSTEM_TIME 			-r 1

# Debug streams
mavlink stream -d /dev/ttyACM0 -s VISION_POSITION_ESTIMATE 	-r 10
mavlink stream -d /dev/ttyACM0 -s LOCAL_POSITION_NED 		-r 10
mavlink stream -d /dev/ttyACM0 -s GLOBAL_POSITION_INT 		-r 10
mavlink stream -d /dev/ttyACM0 -s SYS_STATUS 			-r 5
mavlink stream -d /dev/ttyACM0 -s EXTENDED_SYS_STATE 		-r 5
mavlink stream -d /dev/ttyACM0 -s HOME_POSITION 		-r 1

mavlink boot_complete
```
Note that setting `-r 800000` for `mavlink start` higher/lower _does NOT_ affect anything, and the issue persists.
Setting the `-r 200` for `mavlink stream` higher (without touching anything else) to e.g 250 _DOES_ increase the rate (to something like 210 Hz) but it never reaches the target rate.

From `mavlink status` :

```
instance #0:
        GCS heartbeat:  1182900777 us ago
        mavlink chan: #0
        type:           USB CDC
        flow control:   OFF
        rates:
        tx: 17.202 kB/s

        rate mult: 1.000
        accepting commands: YES
        MAVLink version: 1
        transport protocol: serial (/dev/ttyACM0 @2000000)
``` 

Note that the rate multiplier is 1.0.

And the actual rate I'm getting (for HIGHRES_IMU): 

```
average rate: 186.141
	min: 0.002s max: 0.010s std dev: 0.00172s window: 177
average rate: 184.189
	min: 0.002s max: 0.010s std dev: 0.00197s window: 360

	min: 0.002s max: 0.010s std dev: 0.00199s window: 728
average rate: 184.166
	min: 0.002s max: 0.010s std dev: 0.00197s window: 765
```

@LorenzMeier Your help would be greatly appreciated on this one. Been running into it for ages, and I still don't understand why...  (exactly same as https://github.com/PX4/Firmware/issues/3291). I'm determined to get to the bottom of this, this time.

title: Pixracer has incorrect gyro device ID on some sensor_gyro messages
body:
**Description**

Whilst testing a prototype IMU thermal compensation algorithm here: https://github.com/priseborough/Firmware/tree/sensor_correction-wip

It was noticed that the sensor_correction message occasionally contained an invalid device ID value for the voted gyro when displayed over the nsh console using the listener app . Further investigation using both the sensor_correction-wip branch and origin/master at 3a17c07 showed that the sensor_gyro topic regularly displayed invalid values for device_id. 

**Steps to reproduce**

1) build and load upstream master onto the pixracer:

git fetch origin
git checkout master
git reset --hard origin/master
make distclean
make px4fmu-v4_default upload

2) Connect the debug cable to the serial port and establish an nsh console connection using a serial terminal.

3) Repeatedly enter 'listener sensor_gyro'

Note the value of device_id. It should be the ID for the ICM-20608 or the MPU9250 gyro. Occasionally it returns a random integer.
